original_title: Sri Lanka New Employment Bill will include transgender workers’ rights: Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka’s minister of labor and foreign employment Manusha Nanayakkara has said that Sri Lanka would ensure that these is no discrimination against the transgender community in the new employment bill.
“We will end discrimination by saying ‘kisima bedayakin thorawa’ in the new employment bill,” Nanayakkara said. “The bill will probably be ready in February.

“Currently, there is a lot of discrimination that the transgender community faces in employment,” Nanayakkara told EconomyNext. “The new employment bill will ensure that the discrimination would not continue.”
In September last year, Nanayakkara met with members of the transgender community to discuss their concerns.
The labor ministry plans to align Sri Lanka’s labor laws with the ILO’s C190 and C180, Nanayakkara said.
The “New Employment Bill’s commitment to combat discrimination with a dedicated chapter. Eliminating gender-specific terms for inclusivity,” Nanayakkara has said.
He said Sri Lanka has 16 labor laws including the Employment of Women, Young People and Children Act that prohibits women working at night.
The minister has said this piece of legislation would be reformed under the new employment bill.

Sri Lanka has made an effort to recognize the rights of LGBTQ people by the private member bill pushed by MP Premnath Dolawatte. The bill seeks the repeal of section 365 and 365 (a) of the Penal Code. (Colombo/Jan2/2024)
